comments:
My eclipse install was working just fine until recently.  Since today, 
when I try to start it, it hands with the following output: 
Message: gdkxft: bad app '(null)' - disabling gdkxft 
***WARNING: Gtk+ version too old (major mismatch) 
 
Gdk-CRITICAL **: file gdkpixmap.c: line 62 (gdk_pixmap_new): assertion 
`(window != NULL) || (depth != -1)' failed. 
org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles 
        at java.lang.Throwable.<init>(Throwable.java:96) 
        at java.lang.Error.<init>(Error.java:52) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.SWTError.<init>(SWTError.java:78) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.SWTError.<init>(SWTError.java:67) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.error(Display.java:476) 
        at 
org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.initializeSystemResources(Display.java:878) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.init(Display.java:1070) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Device.<init>(Device.java:96) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<init>(Display.java:277) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.<init>(Display.java:273) 
        at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:1142) 
        at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run(InternalBootLoader.java:739) 
        at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:462) 
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method) 
        at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:244) 
        at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:693) 
        at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:526) 
 
I'm running GTK+ 1.2.10-21 
 
WTF?

Which build are you using? There is an older build of Eclipse which worked on 
GTK1.2 but it has not been touched in months. GTK1.2 is unsupported and the 
best answer is to upgrade to GTK2.0. (I hear) that it takes a bit to upgrade, 
but it is worth it. There has been a ton of re-work done in the GTK code and 
new code is continuously being released.
I'm running GTK2.  The 1.2 is GTK+, of which 1.2 is the most recent version.  wtf?

What build of eclipse are you running?  What has changed in your environment 
(new build of eclipse)?  It still looks to us as if you are running gtk 1.2 not 
gtk 2.0.

Boris, please figure out what is happening.

There are two things I can spot immediately.  First, "major mismatch" means 
1.x.x instead of 2.x.x.  So Eclipse is definitely linking to the wrong Gtk.  To 
verify what's going on, cd to eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_xxx and do

ldd -r libswt-pi-<version>.so

This will recursively show you all the shared objects SWT links to.

Second, gdkxft should NEVER come in the way of Eclipse.  It is an unofficial 
patch for the old gtk1 to support AA fonts.  Since gtk2 supports them natively, 
there is no need for gdkxft, and the system must be configured such that the 
loader does not touch gdkxft when resolving gtk2 libs.
Are you still having this problem?

Yes, I'm still having the problem.  I just went to try the ldd command 
you proposed, but there isn't a libswt-pi<anything>.so file.   
 
Is it not significant that eclipse is complaining about a Gtk+ 
mismatch, rather than a gtk mismatch?  My system has gtk2 and gtk+ 1.2 
installed.

Ok, let's take a closer look.

> there isn't a libswt-pi<anything>.so file

This would be REALLY weird.  libswt-pi-gtk-NNNN.so (where NNNN is an internal 
revision number) is the glue that allows Eclipse to talk to GTK at all.  
Without it, I can't imagine how Eclipse would detect the presence of any GTK 
(1.2 or 2.0) at all.
Did you look in the right place?  In your Eclipse directory, there 
is "plugins/", and inside there is org.eclipse.swt.gtk_2.0.0 (or 2.0.1, 
whichever eclipse you have).  In there, there is os/linux/x86.  That's where 
you will find the two shared objects.  ldd -r will help you know whether you 
link to 1.2 or 2.0.  Please post the results here.

> Is it not significant that eclipse is complaining about a Gtk+ 
> mismatch, rather than a gtk mismatch?

This is just a slight matter of terminology, and definitely is not the cause of 
the bug.

So, I'm seeing a libgtk-x11-2.0, and libgtk-1.2 and a libgdkxft.  Uh?
Extra info: it works as root but not as a non-root user.

Do you still need help figuring out what is wrong with 
your configuration? If so, please could make sure that you
have at least the following packages install:

gtk2-2.0.1
glib2-2.0.1
pango-1.0.1
freetype-2.0.9-2
atk-1.0.1

You can check this by running "rpm -r gtk2"/"rpm -q glib2" if you
have installed the rpms.

Still doesn't run as a user. 
 
brazil 07:13pm-root(1008)# rpm -q gtk2 glib2 pango freetype atk 
gtk2-2.0.2-4 
glib2-2.0.1-2 
pango-1.0.1-1 
freetype-2.0.9-2 
atk-1.0.1-1 
 
So, it looks like everything's there.

This is a configuration problem in your machine and I believe there is not much
we can do to help.
